awd_titl_txt: Conference: The Second U.S.-Korea Synthetic Biology Conference
awd_abstract_narration:
The Second U.S.-Korea Synthetic Biology Conference will focus on the latest advances in synthetic biology research and applications, bringing together key stakeholders from academic institutions in the United States and Republic of Korea. The conference includes talks on a variety of areas of synthetic biology research, and includes group discussions such as biofoundries and the bioeconomy, advancing synthetic biology education, and using synthetic biology to address global grand challenges. As a consequence of these interactions, the conference creates a unique environment for diverse researchers from the United States and Korea to gather and exchange ideas. The conference also provides a venue for discussing synthetic biology research in agriculture, biotechnology and climate change mitigation. Furthermore, the conference aims to give students and early career professionals opportunities to share their work, to network with the foremost leaders in the field, and to develop their careers.

Synthetic biology has enormous potential to revolutionize medicine, agriculture, biotechnology, and energy usage. By sharing knowledge and expertise at the Second U.S.-Korea Synthetic Biology Conference, scientists in the United States and South Korea will advance their research programs in synthetic biology and increase their potential to contribute to these sectors and to the bioeconomy. The conference gathers an interdisciplinary audience to share technical presentations on cutting edge synthetic biology research and applications, and to network and develop relationships for future collaborations. Attendees include leaders in the field, established researchers, early career professionals and trainees who will lead the field in the coming decades. The conference aims to generate promising new approaches in synthetic biology research and to identify key research milestones in synthetic biology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

por.por_cntn:
The Second Korea-US Synthetic Biology Conference

The Second Korea-US Synthetic Biology Conference was held on November 2-3, 2023, at the Lawrence Berkeley National Lab Facility in Emeryville, CA, USA. This conference aimed to foster closer collaboration between the U.S. and Korea in the fields of synthetic biology and biofoundries. The event was financially supported by the National Science Foundation (NSF) from the USA, the National Research Foundation (NRF) from Korea, and the Korea-U.S. Science Cooperation Center (KUSCO) based in the USA.

The conference was co-chaired by Nathan Hillson from Lawrence Berkeley National Lab in the USA, Dong-Myung Kim from Chungnam National University in Korea, and Yong-Su Jin from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign in the USA. It brought together a total of 40 participants, evenly split between representatives from the U.S. and Korea. The NSF supported the attendance of early-career researchers

The scientific program featured 21 presentations and 12 posters covering a wide range of topics related to experimental and computational synthetic biology. Additionally, a breakout group discussion session allowed for more focused dialogue among attendees. A tour of the Lawrence Berkeley National Lab Facility provided participants with firsthand insights into the infrastructure and capabilities available for research and collaboration. Recordings of the presentations are accessible online, providing a valuable resource for those unable to attend in person or wishing to review the content.

In addition to scientific discussions, participants explored ways to foster and strengthen collaborations and personnel exchanges between the U.S. and Korea, particularly in anticipation of a funding announcement in 2024.


Last Modified: 08/01/2024
Modified by: Yong-Su Jin
